findings.title: Insecure Random Number Generation
findings.description: The `Dice` contract implements an optimized commit/reveal RNG scheme but fails to enforce a commitment to the future block number in the commit phase, allowing the caller to arbitrarily choose and pre-calculate a suitable `_commitBlock` argument.

findings.title: User can use any address as referrer to get discount
findings.description: Users can use any (or their own address) as the referrer while calling the method `purchase` to get a referrer bonus and discount.

findings.title: Use call() instead of transfer()
findings.description: The functions `withdraw()`, `purchase()` and `withdrawBonus()` use the `transfer()` function to transfer ETH to `msg.sender`. However, gas prices were changed in the Istanbul hard fork, meaning that the gas stipend forwarded to `msg.sender` may not be enough for smart contract receivers to do basic bookkeeping.

findings.title: _getSecondDiceRoll() is not bound by maxDiceRoll
findings.description: Values returned by _getSecondDiceRoll() can be greater than maxDiceRoll.

findings.title: Unimplemented initial token distribution
findings.description: The contract’s constructor mints all tokens to the deployer and is marked with a TODO comment to set initial token distribution.

findings.title: Use constants instead of magic numbers
findings.description: The code uses hardcoded values in several places instead of using defined constants.

findings.title: Length of arrays as function parameters is not enforced
findings.description: The methods `_enforceOrderLimits` and `addStock` are using a constant to loop over the array parameter and access its elements. Since the array parameter length can be anything, this approach will throw unexpected errors if the array length is smaller than the constant used to iterate.
